sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Israel is a country located in Western Asia along the eastern coast of the Mediterranean Sea. It is known for its historical and religious significance, technological innovation, and diverse cultural heritage.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Jerusalem is Israel’s capital city and holds deep religious importance for Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency of Israel is the Israeli new shekel (ILS).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official languages are Hebrew and Arabic. English is widely spoken, especially in business and education.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Israeli cuisine reflects Middle Eastern and Mediterranean influences, with popular foods such as falafel, hummus, shakshuka, and sabich.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Israel has varied geography, including Mediterranean coastlines, deserts such as the Negev, fertile plains, and mountainous regions.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Israeli culture blends traditions from Jewish communities around the world with Middle Eastern influences, emphasizing family, holidays, and innovation.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourist attractions include the Old City of Jerusalem, the Dead Sea, Masada, Tel Aviv’s beaches, and historical sites in Nazareth.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: The Dead Sea, located partly in Israel, is one of the saltiest bodies of water on Earth and lies at the lowest land elevation on land.

history.event: The Kingdom of Israel and the Kingdom of Judah emerged in the ancient Levant.
Babylonian forces destroyed Jerusalem and the First Temple.
The region came under Roman rule.
Islamic caliphates gained control of the region.
The Ottoman Empire incorporated the region into its territories.
The Balfour Declaration expressed British support for a Jewish homeland.
The State of Israel was declared independent.
The Six-Day War significantly changed regional borders.
